awd_abstract_narration:
Notions of pseudorandomness and quasirandomness have been developed and investigated in several areas of theoretical computer science, combinatorics and number theory (including complexity theory, cryptography, graph theory, additive combinatorics and analytic number theory) to answer such questions such as the following. What does it mean for a fixed object to be "random-like"? Is it possible to turn existence proofs that use the probabilistic method into explicit constructions? Is it possible to simulate randomized algorithms deterministically? When can heuristic arguments that treat the primes as a random set of integers be turned into rigorous proofs? In the setting of additive combinatorics, what is the minimal set of tests that primes have to satisfy in order to guarantee that they contain arithmetic progressions (or other structures)?

At a very high level, the appeal of such notions is that one can easily prove that certain properties are true for random objects, using probabilistic methods, and then transfer such properties to pseudorandom objects, provided that the pseudorandomness ?fools? the probabilistic techniques. A theme of this workshop will be how to leverage weak pseudorandomness properties, fooling simple classes of tests, in order to derive stronger pseudorandomness properties related to more complex tests. The workshop will explore unconditional constructions of pseudorandom objects at the frontier of progress, such as pseudorandom generators for small-space computations, small-depth circuits with modular gates, threshold circuits, and formulas in disjunctive normal form.

The workshop will bring together complexity theorists, combinatorial mathematicians, number theorists, probabilists and algorithm designers interested in the foundations and uses of pseudo-randomness. It will be open to all potential participants, and the workshop findings (including videorecordings of presentations) will be distributed to the public for comment and engagement. The organizers will encourage students to attend the workshop, and will actively recruit scientists from a diversity of backgrounds to contribute to a wide range of applications.

Report on “Proving and Using Pseudorandomness” workshop
Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing, March 6-10, 2017
David Conlon, Russell Impagliazzo, Raghu Meka, Luca Trevisan (organizers)

The second workshop of the semester-long program on “Pseudorandomness” brought together two different but related areas of research in mathematics and computer science. The first is the study of quasi-randomness and structure vs randomness trade-offs in discrete mathematics. This has been an extremely influential area within combinatorics, graph theory, and number theory in the last decade. The second area is the study of pseudorandomness and building pseudorandom generators in complexity theory. While these areas may look a little disparate at first glance, there are by now several connections between the two. The theme of the workshop was to highlight results that use pseudorandomness for other purposes (e.g., compressive sensing, lower bounds, patterns in primes etc.,) as well as those that prove pseudorandomness (e.g., designing pseudorandom generators, explicit constructions of combinatorial objects). The goal of the workshop was to foster more interaction between the two communities by bringing together several leading as well as young researchers from the two fields.

Each day (with the exception of Wednesday) was divided into two halves, with each half focusing on one theme that alternated from being more discrete math oriented to being more directly related to complexity theory. This allowed for the talks to be logically related to each other while also having some variety on each day. Wednesday afternoon was left open to encourage participants to collaborate with each other. There was an open problem session which was useful in drawing the attention of the participants to new challenges.

The talks were all extremely well received. We mention a few highlights below:

Ryan Williams and Omer Reingold kicked of the workshop by speaking about several recent results in the design of deterministic algorithms. Amon Ta-Shma gave a detailed talk on remarkable recent progress that almost settles a longstanding question in derandomization (the construction of small-bias spaces with optimal support size). This talk in particular drew much further discussion among the experts. In the same vein, Mika Goos gave a talk announcing a new result in communication complexity that established a long sought-after universal simulation theorem of communication protocols for lifted functions. Rohit Gurjar spoke about the fantastic recent advances in deterministic isolation lemmas and the design of deterministic algorithms for fundamental algorithmic challenges such as finding matchings in graphs. Piotr Indyk spoke about efficient computation of the Walsh-Hadamard transform highlighting some of the significant applications of pseudorandom objects related to expanders in compressive sensing. Asaf Shapira gave a talk outlining several new results addressing some of the fundamental bottlenecks in regularity lemmas, which are one of the main tools in modern combinatorics and graph theory. Further illustrating the connections between the two areas of research, Jacob Fox gave a wonderful talk titled “Randomness Intuition” detailing instances in discrete mathematics where randomness gives an essentially optimal bound.

Going forward, it is highly likely that the interactions that originated at the workshop will lead to new advances in both fields, thus enriching them both. As one example of the potential here, we mention that Yevgeny Dodis raised several questions about bitcoin in the open problem session that could very well use the expertise of researchers in pseudorandomness from both perspectives.
